{{short description|Building material used in construction during the late Roman Republic and Empire}} [[File:Rome-Pantheon-Interieur1.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]] in [[Rome]] is an example of Roman concrete construction.]]
'''Roman concrete''', also called '''opus caementicium''', was a material used in construction during the late [[Roman Republic]] until the fading of the [[Roman Empire]]. Roman [[concrete]] was based on a [[hydraulic cement|hydraulic-setting cement]]. Recently, it has been found that it materially differs in several ways from modern concrete which is based on [[Portland cement]]. Roman concrete is durable due to its incorporation of [[volcanic ash]], which prevents cracks from spreading. By the middle of the 1st century, the material was used frequently, often brick-faced, although variations in aggregate allowed different arrangements of materials. Further innovative developments in the material, called the [[Concrete Revolution]], contributed to structurally complicated forms, such as the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]] dome, the world's largest and oldest unreinforced concrete dome.<ref name="Ancient Roman Concrete">{{cite web | url=http://www.romanconcrete.com/docs/spillway/spillway.htm | title=The Riddle of Ancient Roman Concrete | publisher=www.romanconcrete.com | work=S Dept. of the Interior, Bureau of Reclamation, Upper Colorado Region | date=February 1993 | accessdate=20 May 2013 | author=Moore, David}}</ref>
Roman concrete was normally faced with stone or brick, and interiors might be further decorated by [[stucco]], [[fresco]] paintings, or thin slabs of fancy colored marbles. Made up of aggregate and cement, like modern concrete, it differed in that the aggregate pieces were typically far larger than in modern concrete, often amounting to rubble, and as a result it was laid rather than poured.<ref>Henig, Martin (ed), ''A Handbook of Roman Art'', p. 30, Phaidon, 1983, {{ISBN|0714822140}}</ref> Some Roman concretes were able to be set underwater, which was useful for bridges and other waterside construction.
It is uncertain when Roman concrete was developed, but it was clearly in widespread and customary use from about 150 BC; some scholars believe it was developed a century before that.<ref>[[Axel Boëthius|Boëthius, Axel]], [[Roger Ling|Ling, Roger]], [[Tom Rasmussen|Rasmussen, Tom]], ''Etruscan and Early Roman Architecture'', pp. 128-129, Yale/Pelican history of art, 1978, Yale University Press, {{ISBN|0300052901}}, 9780300052909, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=1nZswjfqROUC&printsec=frontcover Google Books]</ref>
==Historic references== [[File:Caesarea Concrete Bath.jpg|thumbnail|[[Caesarea Maritima|Caesarea]] is the earliest known example to have used underwater Roman concrete technology on such a large scale.]][[Vitruvius]], writing around 25 BC in his [[De architectura|''Ten Books on Architecture'']], distinguished types of aggregate appropriate for the preparation of [[lime mortar]]s. For [[structural mortar]]s, he recommended [[pozzolana]] (''pulvis puteolanus'' in Latin), the volcanic sand from the beds of [[Pozzuoli]], which are brownish-yellow-gray in color in that area around Naples, and reddish-brown near Rome. Vitruvius specifies a ratio of 1 part lime to 3 parts pozzolana for cement used in buildings and a 1:2 ratio of lime to pozzolana for underwater work, essentially the same ratio mixed today for concrete used in marine locations.<ref>Heather Lechtman and Linn Hobbs "Roman Concrete and the Roman Architectural Revolution", ''Ceramics and Civilization Volume 3: High Technology Ceramics: Past, Present, Future'', edited by W.D. Kingery and published by the American Ceramics Society, 1986; and Vitruvius, Book II:v,1; Book V:xii2</ref>
By the middle of the first century, the principles of underwater construction in concrete were well known to Roman builders. The city of [[Caesarea Maritima|Caesarea]] was the earliest known example to have made use of underwater Roman concrete technology on such a large scale.<ref name="autogenerated1">Lechtman and Hobbs "Roman Concrete and the Roman Architectural Revolution"</ref>
For rebuilding Rome after the [[Great Fire of Rome|fire in 64 AD]], which destroyed large portions of the city, [[Nero]]'s new building code largely called for brick-faced concrete. This appears to have encouraged the development of the brick and concrete industries.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[File:OpusCaementiciumViaAppiaAntica.jpg|thumb|Example of ''opus caementicium'' on a tomb on the ancient [[Appian Way]] in Rome. The original covering has been removed.]]
==Material properties==
Roman concrete, like any [[concrete]], consists of an [[construction aggregate|aggregate]] and hydraulic [[Mortar (masonry)|mortar]] – a binder mixed with water that hardens over time. The aggregate varied, and included pieces of rock, [[ceramic]] tile, and brick rubble from the remains of previously demolished buildings.
[[Gypsum]] and [[calcium oxide|quicklime]] were used as binders. Volcanic dusts, called [[pozzolana]] or "pit sand", were favored where they could be obtained. Pozzolana makes the concrete more resistant to salt water than modern-day concrete.<ref>Wayman, Erin. “The Secrets of Ancient Rome’s Buildings.” Smithsonian.com. 16 November 2011. Retrieved 24 April 2012.</ref> The pozzolanic mortar used had a high content of [[alumina]] and [[silica]]. [[Tuff]] was often used as an aggregate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b05xxl4t|title=Rome's Invisible City - BBC One|website=BBC|accessdate=6 July 2017}}</ref>
Concrete, and in particular, the hydraulic mortar responsible for its cohesion, was a type of structural ceramic whose utility derived largely from its [[Rheology|rheological plasticity]] in the paste state. The setting and hardening of hydraulic cements derived from hydration of materials and the subsequent chemical and physical interaction of these hydration products. This differed from the setting of [[lime mortar|slaked lime mortars]], the most common cements of the pre-Roman world. Once set, Roman concrete exhibited little plasticity, although it retained some resistance to tensile stresses.
The setting of [[geopolymer|pozzolanic cements]] has much in common with setting of their modern counterpart, [[Portland cement]]. The high silica composition of Roman pozzolana cements is very close to that of modern cement to which blast furnace [[slag]], [[fly ash]], or [[silica fume]] have been added.
The strength and longevity of Roman ''marine'' concrete is understood to benefit from a reaction of [[seawater]] with a mixture of [[volcanic ash]] and quicklime to create a rare crystal called [[tobermorite]], which may resist fracturing. As seawater percolated within the tiny cracks in the Roman concrete, it reacted with [[phillipsite]] naturally found in the volcanic rock and created [[Aluminium|aluminous]] tobermorite crystals. The result is a candidate for "the most durable building material in human history". In contrast, modern concrete exposed to saltwater deteriorates within decades.<ref name="WashPost2017">{{cite news |last1=Guarino |first1=Ben |title=Ancient Romans made world's 'most durable' concrete. We might use it to stop rising seas |publisher=[[Washington Post]] |date=4 July 2017 }}</ref><ref name="JacksonMulcahy2017">{{cite journal |last1=Jackson|first1=Marie D.|last2=Mulcahy|first2=Sean R. |last3=Chen|first3=Heng |last4=Li|first4=Yao |last5=Li|first5=Qinfei |last6=Cappelletti|first6=Piergiulio |last7=Wenk|first7=Hans-Rudolf |title=Phillipsite and Al-tobermorite mineral cements produced through low-temperature water-rock reactions in Roman marine concrete |journal=American Mineralogist |volume=102 |issue=7 |year=2017 |pages=1435–1450 |issn=0003-004X |doi=10.2138/am-2017-5993CCBY}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-40494248|title=Scientists explain ancient Rome's long-lasting concrete|first=Matt|last=McGrath|date=4 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=6 July 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> [[File:Torbermorite_CSH_3D_Crystal_Structure_RasMol.gif|thumb|Crystal structure of tobermorite: elementary unit cell]]
Compressive strengths for modern Portland cements are typically at the 50 MPa level and have improved almost ten-fold since 1860.<ref>N. B. Eden and J. E. Bailey, "Mechanical Properties and Tensile Failure Mechanism of a High Strength Polymer Modified Portland Cement", ''J. Mater. Sci.'', 19, 2677–2685 (1984); and Lechtman and Hobbs, "Roman Concrete and the Roman Architectural Revolution"</ref> There are no comparable mechanical data for ancient mortars, although some information about tensile strength may be inferred from the cracking of Roman concrete domes. These tensile strengths vary substantially from the water/cement ratio used in the initial mix. At present, there is no way of ascertaining what water/cement ratios the Romans used, nor are there extensive data for the effects of this ratio on the strengths of pozzolanic cements.<ref>Lechtman and Hobbs, "Roman Concrete and the Roman Architectural Revolution"; see also: C. A. Langton and D. M. Roy, "Longevity of Borehole and Shaft Sealing Materials: Characterization of Ancient Cement Based Building Materials", ''Mat. Res. Soc. SYmp. Proc.'' 26, 543–549 (1984); and Topical Report ONWI-202, Battelle Memorial Institute, Office of Nuclear Waste Isolation, Distribution Category UC-70, National Technical Information Service, U.S. Department of Commerce (1982).</ref>
==Seismic technology== For an environment as prone to [[earthquake]]s as the [[Italian peninsula]], interruptions and internal constructions within walls and domes created discontinuities in the concrete mass. Portions of the building could then shift slightly when there was movement of the earth to accommodate such stresses, enhancing the overall strength of the structure. It was in this sense that bricks and concrete were flexible. It may have been precisely for this reason that, although many buildings sustained serious cracking from a variety of causes, they continue to stand to this day.<ref>W. L. MacDonald, The Architecture of the Roman Empire, rev. ed. Yale University Press, New Haven, 1982, fig. 131B; Lechtman and Hobbs "Roman Concrete and the Roman Architectural Revolution"</ref>
Another technology used to improve the [[strength of materials|strength]] and stability of concrete was its gradation in domes. One example is the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]], where the aggregate of the upper dome region consists of alternating layers of light [[tuff]] and [[pumice]], giving the concrete a density of 1,350 kg/m<sup>3</sup>. The foundation of the structure used [[travertine]] as an aggregate, having a much higher density of 2,200 kg/m<sup>3</sup>.<ref>K. de Fine Licht, The Rotunda in Rome: A Study of Hadrian's Pantheon. Jutland Archaeological Society, Copenhagen, 1968, pp. 89–94, 134–35; and Lechtman and Hobbs "Roman Concrete and the Roman Architectural Revolution"</ref>
==Modern use== Recent scientific breakthroughs examining Roman concrete have been gathering media and industry attention.<ref>Sezen Soyer-Uzun, Sejung Rosie Chae, Chris J. Benmore, Hans-Rudolf Wenk, Paulo J. M. Monteiro, "Compositional Evolution of Calcium Silicate Hydrate (C-S-H) Structures by Total X-Ray Scattering", Journal of the American Ceramic Society, Volume: 95 Issue: 2 Pages: 793-798, February 2012</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://trebcap.com/fixing-canadas-infrastructure-with-volcanoes/ |title= Fixing Canada's Infrastructure with Volcanoes |publisher=Trebuchet Capital Partners Research |accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> Because of its unusual durability, longevity and lessened environmental footprint, corporations and municipalities are starting to explore the use of Roman-style concrete in North America, substituting the coal [[fly ash]] with volcanic ash that has similar properties. Proponents claim that concrete made with volcanic ash can cost up to 60% less because it requires less cement, and that it has a smaller environmental footprint due to its lower cooking temperature and much longer lifespan.<ref name="autogenerated2">Compositional Evolution of Calcium Silicate Hydrate (C-S-H) Structures by Total X-Ray Scattering</ref> Usable examples of Roman concrete exposed to harsh marine environments have been found to be 2000 years old with little or no wear.<ref>M. D. Jackson, S. R. Chae, R. Taylor, C. Meral, J. Moon, S. Yoon, P. Li, A. M. Emwas, G. Vola, H.-R. Wenk, and P. J. M. Monteiro, Unlocking the secrets of Al-tobermorite in Roman seawater concrete, American Mineralogist, Volume 98, pages 1669–1687, 2013.</ref>
==See also== *{{annotated link|Energetically modified cement|abbreviation=EMC}} *{{annotated link|Geopolymer}} *{{annotated link|Roman brick}} *{{annotated link|Pozzolanic reaction}} *{{annotated link|Tobermorite}}
==Literature== *Jean-Pierre Adam, Anthony Mathews, ''Roman Building'', 1994 *Lynne C. Lancaster, ''Concrete Vaulted Construction in Imperial Rome'', Cambridge University Press, 2005 *Heather N. Lechtman & Linn W. Hobbs, “Roman Concrete and the Roman Architectural Revolution,” ''Ceramics and Civilization Volume 3: High Technology Ceramics: Past, Present, Future'', edited by W.D. Kingery and published by the American Ceramics Society, 1986 *W. L. MacDonald, ''The Architecture of the Roman Empire'', rev. ed. Yale University Press, New Haven, 1982
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history-archaeology/The-Secrets-of-Ancient-Romes-Buildings.html The Secrets of Ancient Rome's Buildings] – article on Smithsonian.com *[http://newscenter.lbl.gov/2013/06/04/roman-concrete/ Roman Seawater Concrete Holds the Secret to Cutting Carbon Emissions] – article on [[Lawrence_Berkeley_National_Laboratory|Berkeley Lab]] website

'''<big>Rural management</big>''' is the study of planning, organising, directing, and controlling of [[rural area]], [[Cooperative|co-operatives]], [[agribusiness]] and allied fields. It merges the knowledge of [[Management|management studies]] and applying it in the rural context. Most of the courses are designed in such a way that the concepts taught in the class is applied in the real life through training in the rural areas through [[Case study|case-studies]] and interaction with the rural people
== Rural Management Institutes in India ==
There are many academic institutions within India offering courses on Rural Management. Notable among them are Institute of Rural Management, Anand (www.irma.ac.in), KIIT School of Rural Management (KSRM), Bhubaneswar (ksrm.ac.in) and Xavier University, Bhubaneswar (ximb.ac.in). They offer either two years' Post Graduate Diploma in Rural Management or Two Years' Masters in Business Administration (MBA-Rural Management).
Rural Management graduates work in the areas like sustainable rural livelihoods, agri-business management, cooperatives, climate change, micro-finance, [[corporate social responsibility]], [[Natural resource management|natural resources managemen]]<nowiki/>t, rural marketing, commodity trading and marketing and [[social entrepreneurship]].
Apart from the classroom based courses, IRMA and KSRM provide opportunities to their rural management students to undergo three field segments (internships) of 10–11 weeks duration. In other words, the curriculum is designed to make it contextual to develop rural areas through experiential learning, live projects.
* Institute of Rural Management, Anand, Gujarat, India - www.irma.ac.in * [http://www.ksrm.ac.in/ KIIT School of Rural Management] (MBA-Rural Management)- KIIT University, Bhubaneswar, Odisha, India * Xavier School of Rural Management, Xavier University, Bhubaneswar, Odisha, India www.xsrm.edu.in
== Growing scope of Rural Management in India == India has close to 4,000 management schools that produce over 300,000 graduates every year. But the country has few niche management schools focusing on the rural sector. Rural management schools produce less than 1,000 rural managers. The small number is surprising considering the importance of the rural sector, or Bharat, in India's economy.
According to a study by global consulting firm Accenture, the rural economy accounts for 50 per cent of the country's gross domestic product. It also makes up 70 per cent of the country's population and 50 per cent of the work force. About 75 percent of new factories built in the past decade have come up in rural India, which accounts for 75 per cent of all new manufacturing jobs. Since 2000, per capita GDP has grown at 6.2 per cent a year in rural India compared with 4.2 per cent in urban areas. And in terms of spending, Bharat has trumped India by a mile. Between 2009 and 2012, Indians in the countryside spent $69 billion compared with $55 billion in big towns and cities.
Harish Manwani, chairman of Hindustan Unilever Ltd, says rural India is a powerhouse with the potential to add $1.8 trillion, or the equivalent of the current GDP, to the country's economy. But this potential can be realised only if Bharat and India merge.
Mainstream management schools have not ventured into rural management for many reasons. The rural management courses are very niche and they call for students with a different set of attitudes. The teaching approach is also different. Most mainstream schools may not be prepared to handle such subjects," says Professor Abraham Koshy, professor of marketing at the Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad. Experts say there is room for more rural management schools. For a country of India's size and the number of problems we face, there is a need for lot more such institutions. There is a need to create a lot of rural managers who are potential agents of change.
Rural Management is one such specialisation which gives you the chance to contribute towards uplifting and betterment of those sections of the society, where the light of development is yet to reach. The purpose of the rural managers is to promote sustainable, eco-friendly and equitable socioeconomic development of rural area through professional management of their institutions and organisations. Previously, only a few people opted for this challenging course but nowadays, a lot of students are opting for this course of rural management as they want to learn and showcase their skills to ensure that the performance in the rural sector is enhanced..
== Unique areas of Rural Management in terms of course and career == The MBA (Rural Management) programme is unique in the sense that in addition to traditional management courses such as Project Management, Accounting, Quantitative Techniques, Managerial Analysis and Communication, Finance, Marketing Management, many specialised courses focusing on management of rural sector are offered.
Agribusiness Management, Rural Production and Livelihoods, Rural Finance and Commercial Banking, Natural Resources Management and Climate Change, Rural Marketing, CSR Management, Micro Finance, ICTs for Development, Innovation in Rural Development and Enterprises, Policy and Programme Interventions in Rural Development are some of the courses especially focusing on the rural sector.
Anyone who completes MBA (Rural Management) has the advantage of having career opportunities in any general management area. In addition to that, Rural Management graduates alone are preferred in specific areas mentioned above.

IIM-Lucknow- 2014 *KIIT School of Rural Management (KSRM), Bhubaneswar which came into existence with the laying of the foundation stone by the father of the White Revolution, Late Dr. [[Verghese Kurien]] & [https://achyutasamanta.com/ Dr. Achyuta Samanta] offering MBA (Rural Management) course: http://www.ksrm.ac.in/ *[http://www.ksrm.ac.in/95th-birth-anniversary-of-the-legendary-dr-verghese-kurien/ KSRM Celebrating the 95th Birth Anniversary of the Legendary Dr. Verghese Kurien] *[http://niti.gov.in/writereaddata/files/document_publication/Rural_Economy_DP_final.pdf Changing Structure of Rural Economy of India -Implications for Employment and Growth- NITI Aayog] *[http://www.pondiuni.edu.in/storage/dde/downloads/markiv_rm.pdf Rural Marketing is Real Marketing] *[http://journals.sagepub.com/home/irm# International Journal of Rural Management- international journal that focuses exclusively on rural management] *[http://yojana.gov.in/Final%20Kuru%20December%202015.pdf Social Change in Rural India] *[https://rural.nic.in/ Ministry of Rural Development, Government of India]

[[Olivia Gordon]]
Stefan Chin | country = | language = [[English language|English]] | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | location = [[Missoula, Montana]] | cinematography = | editor = | camera = | runtime = | company = [[Complexly]] | distributor = [[YouTube]] | first_aired = January 2, 2012 | last_aired = | related = | website = https://youtube.com/scishow | website_title = }} '''''SciShow''''' is a series of science-related videos on [[YouTube]]. The program is mainly hosted by [[Hank Green]] of the [[VlogBrothers]] and [[Michael Aranda]].{{cite web|last=Leib|first=Bart|url=https://www.wired.com/geekdad/2012/03/scishow-crash-course/|title=Scishow & Crash Course: Why Isn’t School This Cool?|publisher=''Wired''|work=Geekdad|date=March 23, 2012|accessdate=March 6, 2013}} ''SciShow'' was launched as an [[YouTube Original Channel Initiative|original channel]].{{cite web|last=Eördögh|first=Fruzsina|url=http://www.dailydot.com/entertainment/hank-green-vlogbrothers-scishow-youtube/|title=Watch the premiere of Hank Green's SciShow|publisher=''Daily Dot''|date=January 3, 2012|accessdate=March 6, 2013}} ==Hosting and production== [[File:Hank Green Vlogbrothers 2016.jpg|thumb|Hank Green, host of ''SciShow'']] Though Green hosts the majority of episodes, the show has alternate hosts; [[Michael Aranda]] has been with the show since its inception, and Olivia Gordon of the Missoula Insectarium joined in June 2016.{{cite web|title=New Ancient Human Fossils!|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cqeu49ENGYw|website=SciShow|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=11 June 2016}} Prior to her move to Chicago, [[Emily Graslie]] of ''The Brain Scoop'', also occasionally hosted on the channel. There have also been guest appearances by [[Lindsey Doe]], who hosts ''Sexplanations'', another channel launched by Green; and by longtime SciShow staffer Stefan Chin, who since 2018 has been a regular host. ''SciShow'' has grown since its 2012 launch; since then it has employed a full editorial, production, and operations staff.{{cite web|last=Stone|first=Madeline|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-scishow-and-hank-green-landed-a-national-ad-campaign-from-youtube-2014-10|title=Meet The Science Nerd Whose Face Is About To Be Plastered On YouTube Ads Everywhere|publisher=''Business Insider''|date=October 15, 2014|accessdate=October 25, 2014}} ''SciShow Space'' has three rotating hosts: Hank Green, Reid Reimers, and Caitlin Hofmeister. ''SciShow Kids'' is primarily hosted by Jessi Knudsen Castañeda.{{cite web|title=SciShow Kids|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/scishowkids|website=Youtube|publisher=SciShow|accessdate=July 30, 2015}} ''SciShow Psych'' is co-hosted by Hank Green and Brit Garner.{{cite AV media|last=Green|first=Hank|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wmH9IANu_no |title=SciShow Psych Trailer |publisher=YouTube|work=SciShow|date=February 27, 2017|accessdate=February 27, 2017}} ==Promotion and funding== The channel was launched as an "[[YouTube Original Channel Initiative|original channel]]", which meant that [[YouTube]] funded the channel.{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/vlogbrother-hank-green-launches-science-channel-as-one-youtubes-much-publicized-original-1602880.htm|title=Vlogbrother Hank Green Launches Science Channel as One of YouTube's Much-Publicized Original Programming Channels|publisher=''Market Wired''|date=January 3, 2012|accessdate=October 25, 2014}}{{cite web|last=Hale|first=Mike|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/25/arts/television/youtubes-original-channels-take-on-tv.html|title=Genres Stretch, for Better and Worse, as YouTube Takes On TV|publisher=''New York Times''|date=April 25, 2012|accessdate=October 25, 2014}} The show's initial grant was projected to expire in 2014, and in response, on September 12, 2013 ''SciShow'' joined the viewer-funding site ''Subbable'', created in part by Green.{{cite web|last=Green|first=Hank|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0GE10lpp8O0|title=SciShow Needs You!|publisher=''YouTube''|work=SciShow|date=September 12, 2013|accessdate=October 17, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Eifler|first=Emily|url=http://www.kqed.org/arts/multimedia/article.jsp?essid=124879|title=Crowdfunding Matures with a Lesson from Public Broadcasting|publisher=''KQED''|date=August 20, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} In 2014, the channel landed a national advertisement deal with YouTube. The educational program was featured on platforms such as billboards and television commercials, as a result.{{cite web|last=DeSimone|first=Evan|url=http://newmediarockstars.com/2014/10/hank-green-will-soon-be-stalking-you-with-science/|title=Hank Green Will Soon Be Stalking You With Science|publisher=''New Media Rockstars''|date=October 16, 2014|accessdate=October 25, 2014}} Green details that the advertisements had a positive effect on ''SciShow'', stating, "My Twitter exploded, our followers and subscribers exploded." After [[Patreon]] acquired ''Subbable'', the channel switched over to Patreon where it continues to receive support in exchange for various perks. ''SciShow'' currently has over five thousand patrons.{{Cite news|url=https://www.patreon.com/scishow|title=SciShow is creating YouTube Videos about Science {{!}} Patreon|work=Patreon|access-date=2017-03-11|language=en}} ==Content== Several different scientific fields are covered by ''SciShow'', including [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[biology]], [[zoology]], [[entomology]], [[botany]], [[meteorology]], [[astronomy]], [[medicine]], [[psychology]], [[anthropology]], and [[computer science]].{{cite web|url=http://www.watchdocumentaryfilms.com/scishow-chemistry/|title=SciShow: Chemistry|publisher=''Watch Documentary Films''|accessdate=March 6, 2013}} The videos on ''SciShow'' have a vast variety of different topics, such as nutrition,{{cite web|last=Proefrock|first=Philip|url=http://www.ecogeek.org/agriculture/3739-scishow-the-dark-lord-of-nutrition|title=SciShow: The Dark Lord of Nutrition|publisher=''EcoGeek''|date=April 11, 2012|accessdate=March 6, 2013}} and "science superlatives".{{cite web|last=Leroux-Lindsey|first=Angela|url=http://www.bnl.gov/newsroom/news.php?a=23633|title=YouTube's SciShow Hails Hot Quark-Gluon Plasma as "Superlative Science"|publisher=''Brookhaven National Laboratory''|date=January 18, 2013|accessdate=March 6, 2013}} As of February 2016, ''SciShow'' has released 820 videos.{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZyTGFziTw7k|title = SciShow: Winter Compilation|date = December 23, 2015|accessdate = December 27, 2015|website = YouTube|publisher = |last = |first = }} A spin-off channel, ''SciShow Space'', launched in April 2014 to specialize in [[Outer space|space]] topics.{{cite AV media|last=Green|first=Hank|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g1kvG-wfIz0 |title=SciShow Space Launch|publisher=YouTube|work=SciShow|date=March 26, 2014|accessdate=January 19, 2015}} A second spin-off, ''SciShow Kids'', launched in March 2015 to specialize in delivering science topics to children.{{cite AV media|last=Knudsen Castañeda|first=Jessi|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HAOzlZRGeyY|title=SciShow Kids|publisher=YouTube|work=SciShow|date=February 23, 2015|accessdate=February 23, 2015}} A third spinoff channel was announced in February 2017, ''SciShow Psych'', which debuted in March 2017, specializing in psychology and neuroscience.{{cite AV media|last=Green|first=Hank|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wmH9IANu_no |title=SciShow Psych Trailer |publisher=YouTube|work=SciShow|date=February 27, 2017|accessdate=February 27, 2017}} A [[podcast]], ''SciShow Tangents'', was launched in November 2018; it features entertaining exchanges of scientific facts among many of the shows' staffers, and is directed at a mature audience.{{cite web |title=SciShow Tangents |url=https://www.wnycstudios.org/shows/scishow-tangents |publisher=WNYC Studios |accessdate=30 November 2018}} ===List of segments=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Show !! Debut |- | Dose || January 2, 2012 |- | Infusion || January 8, 2012 |- | Breaking || February 8, 2012 |- | News || February 10, 2012 |- | Great Minds || February 23, 2012 |- | I Don't Think It Means What You Think It Means || May 8, 2012 |- | Talk Show || January 27, 2013 |- | Quick Questions (QQ's) || January 23, 2014 |- | Quiz Show || March 27, 2014 |- | World's Most Asked Questions || October 15, 2014 |} ==Reception== As ''SciShow'' has amassed a large following, the channel has been featured on several media outlets.{{cite web|last=Goodman|first=Will|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504784_162-57507638-10391705/a-double-dose-of-internet-education-for-you-on-the-history-of-cute-and-spam/|title=A double-dose of Internet education for you (on the history of "cute" and "spam")|publisher=''CBS''|work=The Feed|date=September 6, 2012|accessdate=March 9, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Chant|first=Ian|url=http://www.geekosystem.com/starfish-eyes/|title=Recover From The Long Weekend With Weird Science From SciShow [Video]|publisher=''Geekosystem''|date=July 8, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Condliffe|first=Jamie|url=http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2014/07/a-crash-course-in-transistors-processors-and-moores-law/|title=A Crash Course In Transistors, Processors And Moore's Law|publisher=''Gizmodo Australia''|date=July 15, 2014|accessdate=August 1, 2014}}{{cite web|last=Ryan|first=Jessica|url=http://www.coloradodaily.com/cu-boulder/ci_26198244/ryan-boulders-story-group-explores-stories-behind-climate|title=RYAN: Boulder's The Story Group explores stories behind climate change|publisher=''Colorado Daily''|date=July 22, 2014|accessdate=August 1, 2014}} As for the channel's success on YouTube, it was documented that by October 2014, the channel amassed over two million subscribers and earned over 210 million video views. As of May 2017, the channel has over four million subscribers and has over 662 million views. https://www.youtube.com/scishow ''SciShow'' has been criticized by fellow science YouTuber [[Myles Power]] for presenting biased and incorrect information about [[genetic modification]].{{cite web|author=Myles Power|url=http://mylespower.co.uk/2013/02/25/the-biased-views-of-hank-green-and-scishow/|title=The Biased Views of Hank Green and SciShow|publisher=''Myles Power''|date=February 5, 2013|accessdate=September 9, 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Power|first1=Miles|title=SciShow – How Even the Best Science Communicators Can Still Be Wrong|url=http://mylespower.co.uk/2015/07/14/scishow-how-even-the-best-science-communicators-can-still-be-wrong/|accessdate=9 September 2015}} Criticisms were later responded to in a separate response video.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sH4bi60alZU|accessdate=9 September 2015|title=Why are GMOs Bad?|date=10 July 2015|first=Hank|last=Green}} In 2017, SciShow won Complexly's People's Voice award. http://www.webbyawards.com/winners/2017/film-video/video-channels-and-networks/science-education-channels-and-networks/scishow/ ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{YouTube |user=scishow|title=SciShow}} *{{YouTube |user=scishowspace|title=SciShow Space|link=no}} *{{YouTube |user=scishowkids|title=SciShow Kids|link=no}} *{{YouTube |user=scishowpsych|title=SciShow Psych|link=no}} *{{facebook|scishow}} {{VlogBrothers}} [[Category:2012 web series debuts]] [[Category:Green brothers]] [[Category:Non-fiction web series]] [[Category:YouTube channels launched in 2012]] [[Category:Science-related YouTube channels]] [[Category:YouTube funded channels]] [[Category:Science education]] [[Category:English-language YouTube channels]]

{{primary sources|date=January 2016}} [[File:Space Engineers 5.jpg|thumb|''Space Engineers'' video game: 3D spatial navigation]] '''Spatial ability''' or visuo-spatial ability is the capacity to understand, reason and remember the spatial relations among objects or space.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://web.jhu.edu/cty/STBguide.pdf|title = Spatial ability|date = |accessdate = |website = www.jhu.edu|publisher = Johns Hopkins University|last = |first = }}</ref>
Visual-spatial abilities are used for everyday use from navigation, understanding or fixing equipment, understanding or estimating distance and measurement, and performing on a job. Spatial abilities are also important for success in fields such as sports, technical aptitude, [[mathematics]], natural sciences, [[engineering]], economic forecasting, [[meteorology]], [[chemistry]] and [[physics]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = http://web.jhu.edu/cty/STBguide.pdf|title = What is spatial ability?|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = Johns Hopkins University|author = Johns Hopkins University}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|title = Women in Science and Mathematics|url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK23762/|date = 2006-01-01|first = National Academy of Sciences|last = (us)|first2 = National Academy of Engineering|last2 = (us)|first3 = and Institute of Medicine (US) Committee on Maximizing the Potential of Women in Academic Science and|last3 = Engineering}}</ref> Not only do spatial abilities involve understanding the outside world, but they also involve processing outside information and reasoning with it through visual representation in the mind.
== Definition and types == Spatial ability is the capacity to understand, reason and remember the spatial relations among objects or space.<ref name=":0" /> There are four common types of spatial abilities which include spatial or visuo-spatial perception, spatial visualization, mental folding and [[mental rotation]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Impact of cognitive imaging and sex differences on the development of laparoscopic suturing skills|journal = Canadian Journal of Surgery|date = 2005-10-01|issn = 0008-428X|pmc = 3211902|pmid = 16248138|pages = 387–393|volume = 48|issue = 5|first = Tyrone|last = Donnon|first2 = Jean-Gaston|last2 = DesCôteaux|first3 = Claudio|last3 = Violato}}</ref> Each of these abilities have unique properties and importance to many types of tasks whether in certain jobs or everyday life. For example, spatial perception is defined as the ability to perceive spatial relationships in respect to the orientation of one's body despite distracting information.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|title = Emergence and Characterization of Sex Differences in Spatial Ability: A Meta-Analysis|url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/19086027_Emergence_and_Characterization_of_Sex_Differences_in_Spatial_Ability_A_Meta-Analysis|journal = Child Development|pages = 1479–1498|volume = 56|issue = 6|doi = 10.1111/j.1467-8624.1985.tb00213.x|first = Marcia C.|last = Linn|first2 = Anne C.|last2 = Petersen}}</ref> [[mental rotation]] on the other hand is the mental ability to manipulate and rotate 2D or 3D objects in space quickly and accurately.<ref name=":1" /> Lastly, spatial visualization is characterized as complicated multi-step manipulations of spatially presented information.<ref name=":11" /> These three abilities are mediated and supported by a fourth spatial cognitive factor known as spatial working memory. [[Spatial memory|Spatial working memory]] is the ability to temporarily store a certain amount of visual-spatial memories under attentional control in order to complete a task.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|title = A Comparison of Laboratory and Clinical Working Memory Tests and Their Prediction of Fluid Intelligence|journal = Intelligence|date = 2009-05-01|issn = 0160-2896|pmc = 2818304|pmid = 20161647|pages = 283|volume = 37|issue = 3|doi = 10.1016/j.intell.2008.11.005|first = Jill T.|last = Shelton|first2 = Emily M.|last2 = Elliott|first3 = B. D.|last3 = Hill|first4 = Matthew R.|last4 = Calamia|first5 = Wm. Drew|last5 = Gouvier}}</ref> This cognitive ability mediates individual differences in the capacity for higher level spatial abilities such as mental rotation.
=== Spatial perception === [[File:Видеоскриншот из игры S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Mobile.gif|thumb|Action shooting game: Use of spatial perceptual skills]] Spatial perception is defined as the ability to perceive spatial relationships in respect to the orientation of one's body despite distracting information.<ref name=":1" /> It consists of being able to perceive and visually understand outside spatial information such as features, properties, measurement, shapes, position and motion.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.people.fas.harvard.edu/~asimmons/pdfs/PT%20Spatial%20Perception.pdf|title = Spatial Perception from a Cartesian Point of View|last = Simmons|first = Alison|date = 2003|journal = Philosophical Topics |volume=31|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> For example, when one is navigating through a dense forest they are using spatial perception and awareness. Another example is when trying to understand the relations and mechanics inside of a car, he or she is relying on their spatial perception to understand its visual framework. Tests that measure spatial perception include the [[rod and frame test]], where subjects must place a rod vertically while viewing a frame orientation of 22 degrees in angle, or the [[water-level task]], where subjects have to draw or identify a horizontal line in a tilted bottle.<ref name=":11" />
Spatial perception is also very relevant in sports. For example, a study found that [[cricket]] players who were faster at picking up information from briefly presented visual displays were significantly better batsmen in an actual game.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Inspection time and high-speed ball games|journal = Perception|date = 1989-01-01|issn = 0301-0066|pmid = 2628929|pages = 789–792|volume = 18|issue = 6|first = I. J.|last = Deary|first2 = H.|last2 = Mitchell|doi=10.1068/p180789}}</ref> A 2015 study published in the ''[[Journal of Vision]]'' found that soccer players had higher perceptual ability for body kinematics such as processing multitasking crowd scenes which involve pedestrians crossing a street or complex dynamic visual scenes.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Assessment of sport specific and non-specific biological motion perception in soccer athletes shows a fundamental perceptual ability advantage over non-athletes for recognizing body kinematics|journal = Journal of Vision|date = 2015-09-01|issn = 1534-7362|pmid = <!--none-->|pages = 504|volume = 15|issue = 12|doi = 10.1167/15.12.504|first = Thomas|last = Romeas|first2 = Jocelyn|last2 = Faubert}}</ref> Another study published in the ''Journal of Human Kinetics'' on fencing athletes found that achievement level was highly correlated with spatial perceptual skills such as visual discrimination, visual-spatial relationships, visual sequential memory, narrow attentional focus and visual information processing.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Attention, Visual Perception and their Relationship to Sport Performance in Fencing|journal = Journal of Human Kinetics|date = 2013-12-31|issn = 1640-5544|pmc = 3916930|pmid = 24511355|pages = 195–201|volume = 39|doi = 10.2478/hukin-2013-0082|first = Mona Mohamed Kamal|last = Hijazi}}</ref> A review published in the journal of ''[[Neuropsychologia]]'' found that spatial perception involves attributing meaning to an object or space, so that their sensory processing is actually part of semantic processing of the incoming visual information.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = Visual cognition: a new look at the two-visual systems model|journal = Neuropsychologia|date = 2005-01-01|issn = 0028-3932|pmid = 15707914|pages = 301–312|volume = 43|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2004.11.016|first = M.|last = Jeannerod|first2 = P.|last2 = Jacob}}</ref> The review also found that spatial perception involves the [[Visual system|human visual system]] in the brain and the [[Parietal lobe|parietal lobule]] which is responsible for visuomotor processing and visually goal-directed action.<ref name=":2" /> Studies have also found that individuals who played first person shooting games had better spatial perceptual skills like faster and more accurate performance in a peripheral and identification task while simultaneously performing a central search.<ref name="Wu 673–686">{{Cite journal|title = Playing shooter and driving videogames improves top-down guidance in visual search|journal = Attention, Perception, & Psychophysics|date = 2013-05-01|issn = 1943-393X|pmid = 23460295|pages = 673–686|volume = 75|issue = 4|doi = 10.3758/s13414-013-0440-2|first = Sijing|last = Wu|first2 = Ian|last2 = Spence}}</ref> Researchers suggested that, in addition to enhancing the ability to divide attention, playing action games significantly enhances perceptual skills like top-down guidance of attention to possible target locations.<ref name="Wu 673–686" />
=== Mental rotation === [[File:Rubik's cube 2.svg|thumb|[[Rubik's cube]]: a popular puzzle that involves 3D mental rotation]][[Mental rotation]] is the ability to mentally represent and ''rotate'' 2D and 3D objects in space quickly and accurately, while the object's features remain unchanged. Mental representations of physical objects can help utilize problem solving and understanding. For example, Hegarty (2004) showed that people manipulate mental representations for reasoning about mechanical problems, such as how gears or pulleys work.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Online Psychology Laboratory - About Mental Rotation|url = http://opl.apa.org/Experiments/About/AboutMentalRotation.aspx|website = opl.apa.org|accessdate = 2016-01-09}}</ref> Similarly, Schwartz and Black (1999) found that doing such mental simulations such as pouring water improves people's skill to find the solution to questions about the amount of tilt required for containers of different heights and widths.<ref name=":3" /> In the field of sports psychology, coaches for a variety of sports (e.g. basketball, gymnastics, soccer or golf) have promoted players to use mental imagery and manipulation as one technique for performance in their game. (Jones & Stuth, 1997)<ref name=":3" /> Recent research (e.g., Cherney, 2008) has also demonstrated evidence that playing video games with consistent practice can improve mental rotation skills, for example improvements in women's scores after practice with a game that involved a race within a 3-D environment.<ref name=":3" /> Same effects have been seen playing action video games such as [[Unreal Tournament]] as well as the popular mainstream game [[Tetris]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The virtual brain: 30 years of video-game play and cognitive abilities|journal = Frontiers in Psychology|date = 2013-09-13|issn = 1664-1078|pmc = 3772618|pmid = 24062712|volume = 4|doi = 10.3389/fpsyg.2013.00629|first = Andrew J.|last = Latham|first2 = Lucy L. M.|last2 = Patston|first3 = Lynette J.|last3 = Tippett}}</ref> [[Jigsaw puzzle|Jigsaw]] puzzles and [[Rubik's Cube|Rubik's cube]] are also activities that involve higher level of mental rotation and can be practiced to improve spatial abilities over time.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Early Puzzle Play: A predictor of preschoolers’ spatial transformation skill|journal = Developmental Psychology|date = 2012-03-01|issn = 0012-1649|pmc = 3289766|pmid = 22040312|pages = 530–542|volume = 48|issue = 2|doi = 10.1037/a0025913|first = S.C.|last = Levine|first2 = K.R.|last2 = Ratliff|first3 = J.|last3 = Huttenlocher|first4 = J.|last4 = Cannon}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Talent in autism: hyper-systemizing, hyper-attention to detail and sensory hypersensitivity|journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|date = 2009-05-27|issn = 0962-8436|pmc = 2677592|pmid = 19528020|pages = 1377–1383|volume = 364|issue = 1522|doi = 10.1098/rstb.2008.0337|first = Simon|last = Baron-Cohen|first2 = Emma|last2 = Ashwin|first3 = Chris|last3 = Ashwin|first4 = Teresa|last4 = Tavassoli|first5 = Bhismadev|last5 = Chakrabarti}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Adolescence: The Transitional Years|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sz20BQAAQBAJ|publisher = Academic Press|date = 2014-05-10|isbn = 9781483265650|first = J. Roy|last = Hopkins}}</ref>
Mental rotation is also unique and distinct from the other spatial abilities because it also involves areas associated with [[Motor skill|motor simulation]] in the brain.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Neuroimaging studies of mental rotation: a meta-analysis and review|journal = Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date = 2008-01-01|issn = 0898-929X|pmid = 17919082|pages = 1–19|volume = 20|issue = 1|doi = 10.1162/jocn.2008.20013|first = Jeffrey M.|last = Zacks}}</ref>
=== Spatial visualization === Spatial visualization is characterized as complicated multi-step manipulations of spatially presented information.<ref name=":11" /> It involves [[Mental image|visual imagery]] which is the ability to mentally represent visual appearances of an object, and [[Mental image|spatial imagery]] which consists of mentally representing spatial relations between the parts or locations of the objects or movements.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|url = http://ideal-group.org/visualization-research/Spatial-Visualization-Visual-Imagery-and-Mathematical-Problem-Solving-of-Students-with-Varying-Abilities.pdf|title = Spatial Visualization, Visual Imagery, and Mathematical Problem Solving of Students With Varying Abilities|last = Van Garderen|first = Delinda|date = 2006|journal = JOURNAL OF LEARNING DISABILITIES VOLUME 39, NUMBER 6|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Spatial visualization is especially important in the domains of science and technology. For example, an astronomer must mentally visualize the structures of a solar system and the motions of the objects within it.<ref name=":4" /> An engineer mentally visualizes the interactions of the parts of a machine or building that he or she is assigned to design or work with.<ref name=":4" /> Chemists must be able to understand formulas which can be viewed as abstract models of molecules with most of the spatial information deleted; spatial skills are important in restoring that information when more detailed mental models of the molecules are needed in the formulas.<ref name=":4" />
Spatial visualization also involves imagining and working with visual details of measurement, shapes, motion, features and properties through mental imagery and using this spatial relations to derive at an understanding to a problem. Whereas spatial perception involves understanding externally via the senses, spatial visualization is the understanding internally through mental imagery in one's mind.
Another critical spatial visualization ability is '''mental animation'''.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|title = Mental animation in the visuospatial sketchpad: evidence from dual-task studies|journal = Memory & Cognition|date = 1997-05-01|issn = 0090-502X|pmid = 9184484|pages = 321–332|volume = 25|issue = 3|first = V. K.|last = Sims|first2 = M.|last2 = Hegarty|doi=10.3758/bf03211288}}</ref> Mental animation is mentally visualizing the motion and movement of components within any form of system or in general.<ref name=":9" /> It is an ability highly crucial in mechanical reasoning and understanding, for example mental animation in mechanical tasks can involve deconstructing a pulley system mentally into smaller units and animating them in the corresponding sequence or laws in the mechanical system.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Mental animation: inferring motion from static displays of mechanical systems|journal = Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|date = 1992-09-01|issn = 0278-7393|pmid = 1402712|pages = 1084–1102|volume = 18|issue = 5|first = M.|last = Hegarty|doi=10.1037/0278-7393.18.5.1084}}</ref> In short, mental animation is mental imagining how mechanical objects work by analyzing the motion of their smaller parts.
'''Mental folding''' is a complex spatial visualization that involves the ''folding'' of 2D pattern or material into 3D objects and representations.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|title = Mental Paper Folding Performance Following Penetrating Traumatic Brain Injury in Combat Veterans: A Lesion Mapping Study|journal = Cerebral Cortex (New York, NY)|date = 2013-07-01|issn = 1047-3211|pmc = 3673178|pmid = 22669970|pages = 1663–1672|volume = 23|issue = 7|doi = 10.1093/cercor/bhs153|first = Leila|last = Glass|first2 = Frank|last2 = Krueger|first3 = Jeffrey|last3 = Solomon|first4 = Vanessa|last4 = Raymont|first5 = Jordan|last5 = Grafman}}</ref> Compared to other studies, mental folding has had relatively little research and study. In comparison to mental rotation, mental folding is a non-rigid spatial transformation ability which means features of the manipulated object end up changing unlike mental rotation. In rigid manipulations, the object itself is not changed but rather its spatial position or orientation is, whereas in non-rigid transformations like mental folding the object and shapes are changed.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Understanding spatial transformations: similarities and differences between mental rotation and mental folding|journal = Cognitive Processing|date = 2013-05-01|issn = 1612-4790|pmid = 23397105|pages = 105–115|volume = 14|issue = 2|doi = 10.1007/s10339-013-0544-6|first = Justin|last = Harris|first2 = Kathy|last2 = Hirsh-Pasek|first3 = Nora S.|last3 = Newcombe}}</ref> Mental folding in tasks usually require a series of mental rotations to sequentially fold the object into a new one. Classic mental folding tests are the Paper folding task which is similar to [[Origami]]. Origami also requires mental folding by assessing folding a 2D paper enough times to create a 3D figure.<ref name=":10"/>
'''Visual penetrative ability''' is least common spatial visualization task which involves ability to imagine what is inside an object based on the features outside.<ref name=":12" />
== Spatial working memory == [[Spatial memory|Spatial working memory]] is the ability to temporarily store visual-spatial memories under [[attentional control]], in order to complete a task.<ref name=":8" /> This cognitive ability mediates individual differences in the capacity for higher level spatial abilities, such as mental rotation. Spatial working memory involves storing large amounts of short-term spatial memories in relation to visuo-spatial sketchpad. It is used in the temporary storage and manipulation of visual-spatial information such as memorizing shapes, colours, location or motion of objects in space. It is also involved in tasks which consist of planning of spatial movements, like planning one's route through a complex building. The visuospatial sketchpad can be split into separate visual, spatial and possibly kin-aesthetic (movement) components. Its neurobiological function also correlates within the right [[Cerebral hemisphere|hemisphere]] of the brain.<ref>{{cite journal |doi = 10.1016/S1364-6613(00)01538-2|last1 = Baddeley|first1 = A.D.|year = 2000|title = The episodic buffer: A new component of working memory?|url = |journal = Trends in Cognitive Sciences|volume = 4|issue = 11|pages = 417–423|pmid = 11058819}}</ref>
== Vocational applications == Researchers have found that spatial ability plays an important role in advanced educational credentials in the science, technology, engineering or math (STEM).<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|url = https://my.vanderbilt.edu/smpy/files/2013/02/Wai2009SpatialAbility.pdf|title = Spatial Ability for STEM Domains: Aligning Over 50 Years of cumulative psychological Knowledge solidifies Its importance|last = Wai|first = Jonathan|date = 2009|journal = Journal of Educational Psychology|doi = 10.1037/a0016127|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Why do spatial abilities predict mathematical performance?|journal = Developmental Science|date = 2014-05-01|issn = 1363-755X|pmc = 3997754|pmid = 24410830|pages = 462–470|volume = 17|issue = 3|doi = 10.1111/desc.12138|first = Maria Grazia|last = Tosto|first2 = Ken B.|last2 = Hanscombe|first3 = Claire M.A.|last3 = Haworth|first4 = Oliver S.P.|last4 = Davis|first5 = Stephen A.|last5 = Petrill|first6 = Philip S.|last6 = Dale|first7 = Sergey|last7 = Malykh|first8 = Robert|last8 = Plomin|first9 = Yulia|last9 = Kovas}}</ref> From studies, it has been indicated that the probability of getting an advanced degree in STEM increases in positive relation to the level of one's spatial ability. For example, a 2009 study published in the [[Journal of Educational Psychology]] found that 45% of those with [[Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics|STEM]] PhDs were within top percentage of high spatial ability in a group of 400,000 participants who were analyzed for 11 years since they were in the 12th grade.<ref name=":5" /> Only less than 10% of those with [[Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics|STEM]] PhDs were below the top quarter in spatial ability during adolescence.<ref name=":5" /> The researchers then concluded how important spatial ability is for [[Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics|STEM]] and as a factor in achieving advanced educational success in that field.<ref name=":5" />
Spatial visualization is especially important in [[science]] and [[technology]]. For example, an [[astronomer]] must visually imagine the structures of a solar system, and the path of the bodies within it.<ref name=":4" /> An engineer must visually imagine the motions of the parts of a machine or building that he or she is assigned to work with.<ref name=":4" /> Chemists must be able to understand formulas which are essentially abstract models supposed to represent spatial dynamics of molecules, and thus spatial skills are important in visualizing the molecule models that are needed in the formulas.<ref name=":4" /> Spatial manipulation ability is also important in the field of structural geology, when visually imagining how rocks change through time, such as migration of a magma body through crust or progressive folding of a strati-graphic succession. Another spatial visualization skill known as ''visual penetrative ability'' is important in geology as it requires geologists to visualize what is inside of a solid object based on past knowledge.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|url = http://nagt-jge.org/doi/pdf/10.5408/1.3559671|title = Characterizing and Improving Spatial Visualization Skills|last = Titus|first = Sarah|date = 2009|journal = Journal of Geoscience Education|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Current literature also indicates that mathematics involves visuo-spatial processing. Studies have found that gifted students in math, for instance, perform better in spatial visualization than non-gifted students.<ref name=":6" /> A 2008 review published in the journal of ''Neuroscience Biobehavioural Reviews'' found evidence that visuo-spatial processing is intuitively involved in many aspects of processing numbers and calculating in math. For example, meaning of a digit in a multi-digit number is coded following spatial information given its relation to its position within the number.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Visualizing numbers in the mind's eye: the role of visuo-spatial processes in numerical abilities|journal = Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews|date = 2008-10-01|issn = 0149-7634|pmid = 18584868|pages = 1361–1372|volume = 32|issue = 8|doi = 10.1016/j.neubiorev.2008.05.015|first = Maria Dolores|last = de Hevia|first2 = Giuseppe|last2 = Vallar|first3 = Luisa|last3 = Girelli}}</ref> Another study found that numerical estimation might rely on integrating different visual-spatial cues (diameter, size, location, measurement) to infer an answer.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The role of visual information in numerosity estimation|journal = PLOS ONE|date = 2012-01-01|issn = 1932-6203|pmc = 3355123|pmid = 22616007|pages = e37426|volume = 7|issue = 5|doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0037426|first = Titia|last = Gebuis|first2 = Bert|last2 = Reynvoet}}</ref> A study published in 2014 also found evidence that mathematical calculation relies on the integration of various spatial processes.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Doing arithmetic by hand: hand movements during exact arithmetic reveal systematic, dynamic spatial processing|journal = [[Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology]]|date = 2014-01-01|issn = 1747-0226|pmid = 25051274|pages = 1579–1596|volume = 67|issue = 8|doi = 10.1080/17470218.2014.897359|first = Tyler|last = Marghetis|first2 = Rafael|last2 = Núñez|first3 = Benjamin K.|last3 = Bergen}}</ref> Another 2015 study published in the journal of ''[[Frontiers in Psychology]]'' also found that numerical processing and arithmetic performance may rely on visual perceptual ability.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Visual perception can account for the close relation between numerosity processing and computational fluency|journal = Frontiers in Psychology|date = 2015-01-01|issn = 1664-1078|pmc = 4563146|pmid = 26441740|pages = 1364|volume = 6|doi = 10.3389/fpsyg.2015.01364|first = Xinlin|last = Zhou|first2 = Wei|last2 = Wei|first3 = Yiyun|last3 = Zhang|first4 = Jiaxin|last4 = Cui|first5 = Chuansheng|last5 = Chen}}</ref>
A 2007 study published in the journal of [[Cognitive science|''Cognitive Science'']] also found that spatial visualization ability is crucial for solving [[Kinematics|kinematic]] problems in physics. Nonetheless, current literature indicates that spatial abilities specifically mental rotation, is crucial for achieving success in various fields of chemistry, engineering and physics.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Spatial Ability in Learning Engineering Mechanics: Critical Review|url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/282853648_Spatial_Ability_in_Learning_Engineering_Mechanics_Critical_Review|website = ResearchGate|access-date = 2016-01-15|doi = 10.1061/(ASCE)EI.1943-5541.0000266}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Mechanical aptitude]] *[[Motor imagery]] *[[Raven's progressive matrices]] *[[Spatial contextual awareness]]
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20151101032114/http://www.engr.psu.edu/awe/secured/director/assessment/Literature_Overview/PDF_overviews/VisualSpatialWeb%2003_22_05.pdf Overview-Visual Spatial skills] * [http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/recognizing-spatial-intel/ Recognizing Spatial Intelligence] * [http://psychometrics.akresgr.org/spatialtest/ Spatial Ability Test,] ''Alaska Research Group''.

{{about|the approach to teaching law}}
'''Street Law''' (also known as ''StreetLaw'') is a global program of legal and civics education geared at secondary school students. Street Law is an approach to teaching practical law to grassroots populations using interactive teaching methodologies. Elements of practical law taught include awareness of human rights/civil rights, democratic principles, conflict resolution, the advocacy process, criminal and civil law, employment law, family law, and consumer rights.
==History==
The Street Law approach began in 1972 when [[Georgetown University Law Center]] developed a program that sent law students into high schools in Washington, DC to teach practical law lessons to high school students. Street Law, Inc., an outgrowth of the Georgetown program, develops and implements practical law education programs around the world.<ref>http://www.georgetown.edu/news/street-law-clinic-celebrates-40-years-in-operation.html</ref> Street Law, Inc. is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization. Its main offices are located in Silver Spring, Maryland, USA.
==Organizational structure==
Although Street Law traces its founding to Georgetown Law, it has spread to many law schools globally. Neither Georgetown Law nor Street Law, Inc. exercise vertical or indirect control over local Street Law programs. Within U.S. law schools, Street Law is typically run as a [[legal clinic]] or experiential learning module, where law students receive law school academic credit for participation. At other law schools, Street Law is run as a [[student organization]] or as an extracurricular activity, typically under direct faculty supervision.
==Pedagogical methodology==
One core Street Law module is a teaching program wherein law students are sent into community schools to teach high school students age appropriate lessons in the law. Within the U.S., this means that second and third year law students are paired with secondary school classes where they regularly teach courses on law and legal subjects. There is significant autonomy and differentiation in the way that Street Law is taught nationally in the U.S. and globally, and Street Law expressly encourages law schools and law students to experiment with different teaching methodologies to account for different learning styles depending on age, culture, regional and state differences, and so on.
Other Street Law approaches include: teaching Legal Life Skills to underserved populations; Teacher Professional Development courses; partnerships with the legal community (both law firm and corporate) to teach about the law and legal careers to secondary students; teaching about rule of law, democracy and civil rights to populations in countries outside of the US; and publishing teaching resources.
==Teaching resources==
Among other publications, [[McGraw-Hill]] has published a high school social studies textbook using this approach.<ref>{{cite book|title=Street Law: A Course in Practical Law|last1=Arbetman|first1=Lee|last2=O'Brien|first2=Edward L.|publisher=Glencoe/McGraw-Hill|year=2016|isbn=9780021429257|edition=9th|location=|pages=}}</ref>
[[McGraw-Hill]] has also published a high school government textbook co-authored by Street Law.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Remy, Ph.D.|first1=Richard C.|last2=Ritchie, Ph.D.|first2=Donald A.|last3=Arbetman, M.Ed., J.D.|first3=Lee|last4=Hanson, M.S.|first4=Hanson|last5=Morreale Scott, Ed.M.|first5=Lena|title=United States Government: Our Democracy|date=2018|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|isbn=9780076681136|edition=1st|language=English}}</ref>
[[McGraw-Hill]] also publishes ''Street Law: Understanding Law and Legal Issues'', an informative law-based, civic learning text for use in the community college program.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Arbetman|first1=Lee|last2=O'Brien,|first2=Edward|title=Street Law: Understanding Law and Legal Issues|date=2012|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|isbn=9780076624058|edition=1st}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Centre for Clinical Legal Education (Palacký University, Faculty of Law)]] * [[Legal clinic]] * [[Legal awareness]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.law.georgetown.edu/academics/academic-programs/clinical-programs/our-clinics/DC-Street-Law-Program/about-our-clinic.cfm/ Georgetown Street Law Clinic] *[http://www.streetlaw.org/en/home/ StreetLaw]

{{more footnotes|date=October 2017}} {{refimprove|date=October 2017}} A '''systems integrator''' (or '''system integrator''')<ref name=howtoworkwith>[http://www.controleng.com/single-article/how-to-work-with-a-system-integrator/3c1415491ee4507df6083049b64978ff.html How to Work with a System Integrator]</ref><ref name=whatdoesitmean>[https://www.thinkesi.com/System-Integrator-Paul-Oswald What Does It Mean To Be A System Integrator]</ref><ref name=fixdata>[http://dvsum.com/automated-testing-data-quality-integrity-missing-weapon-system-integrators-arsenal/ Fix Data: How System Integrators Can Ensure Project Success]</ref> is a person or company that specializes in bringing together component subsystems into a whole and ensuring that those subsystems function together,<ref name=whatdoesitmean/><ref>[https://www.pcmag.com/encyclopedia/term/52450/systems-integrator Definition of: systems integrator] From PC World</ref> a practice known as [[system integration]]. They also solve problems of [[automation]].<ref name=howtoworkwith/> Systems integrators may work in many fields but the term is generally used in the [[information technology]] (IT) field such as [[computer network]]ing, the [[defense industry]], the [[mass media]], [[enterprise application integration]], [[business process management]] or manual [[computer programming]].<ref name="Info">{{Citation| last=Moore | first=June | date =13 December 1982| contribution= Software Reviews, BusinessMaster II+, ledger for CP/M systems| title=InfoWorld | publisher=InfoWorld Media Group, Inc| page = 31 | issn=0199-6649}}</ref> [[Data quality]] issues are an important part of the work of systems integrators.<ref name=fixdata/>
== Required skills == A system integration engineer needs a broad range of skills and is likely to be defined by a breadth of knowledge rather than a depth of knowledge. These skills are likely to include [[software architecture|software]], [[systems architecture|systems]] and [[enterprise architecture|enterprise]] architecture, [[software engineering|software]] and [[hardware engineering|hardware]] engineering, [[Protocol (computing)|interface protocols]], and general problem solving skills. It is likely that the problems to be solved have not been solved before except in the broadest sense. They are likely to include new and challenging problems with an input from a broad range of engineers where the system integration engineer "pulls it all together."<ref name="BUPT">{{Citation |title=An Introduction to School of Information Engineering, Information Engineering Program|publisher=Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications|location=Beijing }}</ref>
==Performance technology Integration==
Systems integrators generally have to be good at matching clients needs with existing products. An [[inductive reasoning aptitude]] is useful for quickly understanding how to operate a system or a [[Graphical user interface|GUI]]. A systems integrator will tend to benefit from being a generalist, knowing a lot about a large number of products. Systems integration includes a substantial amount of diagnostic and troubleshooting work. The ability to research existing products and software components is also helpful. Creation of these information systems may include designing or building customized vehicle prototypes or concepts for future investors and sponsors for a good model or example of the revamped integrations to come - [[Hybrid Technology]], [[Electric]]{{dn|date=September 2017}}, [[Turbocharged]], [[Svt]]{{dn|date=September 2017}}, [[McLaren]], Greenwood, [[Ac shnitzer]],[are some of the specialized teams of Factory/Performance integration that drives auto designers to stay competitive and keep the cutting edge feel in any Brand from Dodge to Pagani there are areas for improvement that can only be tweaked and twisted to stay a cut above the rest and maintain the physical appearance of the specialty teams trademark modifications.{{clarify|date=September 2017}}
==In the defense industry==
In the defense industry, the job of 'Systems Integration' engineer is growing in importance as defense systems become more 'connected'. As well as integrating new systems, the task of integrating current systems is attracting a lot of research and effort. It is only in recent years that systems have started to be deployed that can interconnect with each other; most systems were designed as 'stovepipe' designs with no thought to future connectivity.
The current problem is how to harness all the information available, from the various information generators (or sensors) into one complete picture.
As well as the design of the actual interfaces much effort is being put into presenting the information in a useful manner. The level of information, needed by the different levels in the military structure, and the relevance of the information (information can become outdated in seconds) is so variable that it may be necessary to have more than one system connected.
Another problem is how information is networked. The Internet may seem to be an obvious solution, but it is vulnerable to [[denial of service]] and physical destruction of the key 'hubs'. One answer is to use a dedicated military communication system, but the [[Throughput|bandwidth]] needed would be astronomical in such a system.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}
Army [[Warrant Officer (United States)]] military occupational specialty (MOS) 140A - Command and Control Systems Technician is an example of a systems integrator in the defense industry. 140A Warrant Officers assigned to Brigade Combat Teams (BCT) integrate systems with multiple [[operating systems]] (OS) and hardware configurations – that include: [[UNIX]], [[Linux]] & [[Microsoft Windows]] Others can fill a similar role at the Division level and higher.
==In Entertainment and architectural controls==
In entertainment and architectural installations, systems integrators function as a designer/engineer, bringing together a wide array of components from various manufacturers to accomplish the goal of creating a unified, functioning system that meets the needs of the client. Systems Integrators are usually involved in the selection of instruments and control components from among various [[OEMs]] to determine the specific mix of output, function, interconnection, program storage, controls, and user interfaces required for specific projects. The integrator is generally responsible for generating the control riser, collaborating with the lighting consultant/ AV consultant on the function programming, and will commission the system once installed. Often (but not always) the system integrator will also be the vendor for projects they are commissioning, and will collaborate with the lighting designer on the artistic design. As lighting and A/V systems increase in their level of sophistication, and the number of manufacturers for components of these systems increases, so does the demand for systems integrators.
Common data protocols involved in entertainment and architectural systems are [[DMX512-A|Digital Multiplexing (or DMX512-A)]], [[RDM (lighting)|Remote Device Management (or RDM)]], [[Art-Net]], [[Architecture for Control Networks|ACN]] or sACN (Streaming Architecture for Control Networks), Analog, and various proprietary control software from a variety of manufacturers. Systems Integrators design many distributed nodes in traditional star or ring topologies, or customize system layout for specific installations. The network will have a hierarchy of main and sub-control stations with varying degrees of access. The network can be designed such that the controls for this system can be on an established timeline, or controlled in real time by astronomical clocks, audio/motion/IR sensors, or various means of user interface (buttons, touch-pads, consoles). This system might utilize a primary controller that can access the entire system, and satellite control interfaces linked via a network backbone that would determine functionality based on access codes. For example, a casino might use a networked system that interfaces with architectural lighting, stage lighting, special effects (such as fog machines or fountains), and media content routed to a media server. The primary controller would have access to all devices on the network, while individual control stations could have varying levels of functionality. A ballroom might have a multi-button panel that would adjust lighting only in that ballroom, while a cabaret space with a stage would require an access code that would give employees access to the stage lighting, while the IT manager could use the same panel to access the main controls for the networks.
== In the automation industry == {{main article|Automation integrator}} System Integrators in the automation industry typically provide the product and application experience in implementing complex automation solutions. Often, System Integrators are aligned with automation vendors, joining their various System Integrator programs for access to development products, resources and technical support. System integrators are tightly linked to their accounts and often are viewed as the engineering departments for small manufacturers, handling their automation system installation, commissioning and long term maintenance.
==See also== *[[Enterprise application integration]] *[[Control System Integrators Association]] *[[Electronic Data Interchange|EDI]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Systems engineering]]
